WASHINGTON Election officials in three Pennsylvania counties said they believed no ballots had been wrongly counted as a result of computer malfunctions
column2: despite reports on Tuesday that touch-screen voting machines in the state were switching votes.Officials in Cumberland
column3: Perry and Butler Counties in Pennsylvania told Reuters that they had no reason to believe the mistakes were affecting voters from one party more than the other
column4: and that voters were catching the mistakes on ""review screens"" before their ballots were cast.

By Axel Bugge
| LISBON
LISBON Wikileaks founder Julian Assange said on Tuesday the group's publication of material linked to Hillary Clinton was not based on any desire to influence the U.S. election.""In recent months
column2: WikiLeaks and I personally have come under enormous pressure to stop publishing what the Clinton campaign says about itself to itself
column3: Assange said in a statement released by his legal adviser at the Web Summit
column4: a tech conference in Lisbon.""This is not due to a personal desire to influence the outcome of the election.""WikiLeaks has in the past few months published thousands of emails hacked from John Podesta
column5: Democrat candidate Clinton's campaign manager. Assange said Wikileaks had obtained no inside information about Republican candidate Donald Trump.

column1: We cannot publish what we do not have
column2: he said.""We are seen as domain experts on Clinton archives. So it is natural that Clinton sources come to us
column3: Assange said.

column1: No-one disputes the public importance of these publications
column2: he added.""It would be unconscionable for WikiLeaks to withhold such an archive from the public during an election.""Assange said WikiLeaks would continue to publish sensitive information regardless of who wins the U.S. election.

column1: The Democratic and Republican candidates have both expressed hostility towards whistleblowers

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-ballotinitiative-energy-idUSKBN13323X	Factbox: Clean energy faces vote in four state ballot initiatives	"
In addition to picking the next U.S. president on Tuesday
column2: voters in four states will decide on ballot initiatives related to energy and the environment.The results of the initiatives could offer a gauge of Americans' feelings about managing carbon dioxide emissions
column3: regulating solar power
column4: and handling local opposition to hydraulic fracturing.Here are descriptions of the various initiatives:WASHINGTON STATE CARBON TAX

column1: Washington state voters will decide whether to adopt a measure to create the country's first carbon tax. Initiative 732 would slap a $15 price tag on a ton of carbon for utilities and refiners in 2017
column2: with the price rising gradually each year until it reaches $100. The tax would be revenue neutral: money raised would replace old revenue from sales and business taxes.Supporters say the tax would bring down emissions without burdening state residents. But the measure has brought together unlikely allies from industry groups who say it would hurt businesses' bottom lines and environmental organizations like the Sierra Club who say it does not create new revenue to invest in clean energy and mass transit. Other groups argue it could hurt lower-income communities.FLORIDA SOLAR

column1: Florida's electric utilities have sponsored a measure that could affect how the state regulates private use of solar energy. A confusingly worded Amendment 1 would alter the state's constitution to protect the right to own or lease solar equipment
column2: while also ensuring that electricity consumers who do not use solar energy ""are not required to subsidize the costs of back-up power and electric grid access to those who do.""Supporters say it enshrines the rights of solar users
column3: but opponents say it is a sneaky way of letting the state block 'net metering
column4: ' in which a solar user can sell unused energy on the grid at market value. Floridians for Solar Choice say the measure would ""choke off"" the state's nascent rooftop solar industry.COLORADO FRACKING

column1: Colorado voters will vote on a measure that would make it harder to change the state's constitution by requiring broad support across all state districts for signatories to petitions and a higher percentage threshold  to be approved. Opponents of hydraulic fracturing
column2: an oil and gas drilling technique they say causes water pollution
column3: claim Amendment 71 would make it harder for local communities to block fracking projects.The amendment was written and funded by oil and gas industry groups but does not directly address the controversial practice. Colorado is one of several U.S. states that has seen a surge in fracking in recent years. Scores of towns across the country
column4: including several in Colorado
column5: have tried to ban it.

column1: NEVADA'S ENERGY CHOICE INITIATIVE

Nevada voters will decide whether to open up the state's energy market to competition by giving consumers the option to decide where they buy their power.The measure comes after state regulators last year approved a rate increase for customers with rooftop solar panels
column2: causing solar companies to lay off workers. Currently
column3: Nevada law allows investor-owned utility companies to be monopolies in their service territories.Supported by environmentalists as well as electric carmaker Tesla
column4: MGM Resorts and other companies
column5: the measure would let consumers choose an energy provider and sell the solar electricity they generate themselves. Big companies that want to leave the grid can do so by paying hefty penalties to state regulators.If passed
column6: the measure would direct the Nevada Legislature to pass legislation to create an open
column7: competitive electricity market by mid-2023. (Reporting by Valerie Volcovici in Washington; Editing by Jeffrey Benkoe)"

column1: By Linda Sieg and Gayatri Suroyo
| TOKYO/JAKARTA
TOKYO/JAKARTA Win or lose
column2: Donald Trump's campaign has changed the way countries in Asia view their relationships with Washington.Final polling suggests the most likely outcome is a victory for Hillary Clinton. But even Clinton
column3: an architect of the U.S. strategic pivot to Asia
column4: has some work ahead of her in rebuilding trust
column5: analysts and former officials in Asia said.""With or without Trump
column6: this marks the end of U.S. leadership
column10: who asked not to be identified because of the sensitivity of the topic.""I don't think it's a question of Trump as an individual
column11: but a question of the U.S. society that produced this man as the Republican candidate.""Trump upended U.S. democratic traditions during his White House campaign
column12: drawing enthusiastic crowds where people cheered his often provocative and outrageous remarks. Critics labeled him ignorant
column17: all accusations he denied. He described a dark America
column18: knocked to its knees by China
column19: Mexico and the Islamic state. Trump's harnessing of a populist backlash against immigration and global trade has challenged the ideal of benevolent American power that helped shape the global economy - and the forces of globalization - since the fall of the Soviet Union in the early 1990s.Now the United States faces a rising China
column20: long an economic force and now becoming more assertive in geopolitics -  building its military capability and ignoring an international tribunal's ruling against its claims to most of the South China Sea.TRANS-PACIFIC PARTNERSHIP

column1: Asia is most worried about trade protectionism - exports make up a quarter of Asia's GDP and a fifth of them go to the United States.
The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal
column2: championed by Barack Obama in part to increase U.S. influence in Asia
column3: was to be an essential feature of Washington's strategic pivot to Asia - an ""economic NATO"".  It now looks dead in the water. Both Clinton and Trump oppose the deal
column4: which would set up a free trade zone among 12 countries that excludes China.Former Indonesian finance minister Chatib Basri told Reuters the TPP ""is an important instrument for the U.S. pivot to Asia"".""There is some kind of a rivalry between America and China
column5: and the way America can get into Asia is with TPP
column7: now a visiting professor at Australian National University.With U.S. allies such as Japan
column9: Taiwan and Singapore among the biggest winners of an open trade regime
column10: a more isolationist and protectionist stance will cost Washington influence in Asia. Ironically
column12: the subject of many of Trump's tirades
column13: that could emerge the big winner as uncertainty over Washington's future commitment to Asia pushes countries into dealing more closely with Beijing.

column1: If the U.S. pulls out of TPP
column2: that will certainly increase China's influence in Asia
column3: said Kanti Bajpai
column4: Professor of Asian Studies at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy in Singapore.""Already
column5: U.S. criticism of domestic issues in Thailand
column7: and Malaysia has alienated those countries and caused them to lean towards Beijing. Pulling out of the TPP will help China geopolitically.""      Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has been particularly hostile towards Washington over its criticism of his lethal anti-drugs campaign
column8: announcing a ""separation"" from the United States during last month's visit to China.Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak came back from a visit to China last week with $34 billion worth of deals and an agreement to buy four Chinese naval vessels.       SECURITY WORRIES

column1: China has long been in Trump's sights
column2: with promises to declare it a currency manipulator and impose punitive tariffs on imports. But any such moves could also hurt Asian exporters who ship components there for assembly and export to the United States
column3: at a time when global trade is already weakening.Gareth Leather
column4: senior Asia economist at Capital Economics
column5: said the Philippines
column6: Taiwan and South Korea were the emerging Asia economies most vulnerable to a Trump presidency.""Perhaps the biggest risk to the region's economies
column8: stems not from Trump's trade policies
column10: Leather said.Trump has created doubts over his commitment to security alliances
column11: suggesting Japan and South Korea need to pay more for a U.S. military presence and that they should even develop their own nuclear capability to counter China and North Korea.Clinton
column12: who was secretary of state when the Obama administration launched its Asia pivot
column13: is expected to maintain Obama's foreign policy
column14: with some seeing her as being more hawkish.The divisive U.S. presidential campaign has already done a lot of damage to the reputation of the United States in Asia
column16: according to some analysts.""The broader question is whether the United States can assert global leadership
column18: CEO at fund manager WisdomTree Japan. ""All my Chinese friends say
column19: 'We thought we would run the world in 20 years. Now it's going to be in January'. This is not a joke. It's the natural state of development
column20: Koll said  (Additional reporting: Nicole Nee in Singapore. Writing by John Mair. Editing by Bill Tarrant.)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-russia-idUSKBN1330K9	Russia to bar U.S. diplomats from monitoring its elections: RIA	"

7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-hatespeech-insight-idUSKBN13225X	Hate speech seeps into U.S. mainstream amid bitter campaign	"
By Peter  Eisler
| KOKOMO
column2: Indiana

column1: KOKOMO
column2: Indiana The lettering is crude
column3: scrawled in black spray paint on the sidewalk in front of Karen Peters' neatly kept home in the quiet
column4: working class neighborhood where she's lived most of her life. But the contempt is clear.    ""KKK Bitch.""    The racially charged graffiti appeared in mid-October on cars
column5: homes and telephone poles in the small city of Kokomo
column9: though some were not. Many also had lawn signs for Democratic candidates in this week's presidential election
column10: and the signs at several homes were painted over with the Ku Klux Klan's notorious initials.    ""I think it's a political thing; it's getting out of hand
column12: who believes the heated tenor of the presidential campaign - and especially the aggressive
column13: nativist rhetoric of Republican candidate Donald Trump - has emboldened extremists.    ""When you have (candidates) saying ignorant things
column14: maybe other people think it's ok to do this stuff
column15: and that's pretty doggone sad ... It seems like our country is going backwards.""    Police have no suspects in the attacks. Democrats
column16: including the mayor and local party officials
column17: believe they were politically motivated. Local Republicans are skeptical
column18: suggesting the damage is the work of ignorant hooligans with no place in the party.         Across the United States
column19: the inflammatory and confrontational tone of political rhetoric is creeping into public discourse and polarizing the electorate.    It's hard to quantify the impact; there is no national data that tracks politically motivated crimes or incendiary speech. However
column20: the percentage of voters who believe insulting political opponents is ""sometimes fair game"" has climbed over the campaign season
column21: from 30 percent in March to 43 percent in October
column22: according to surveys by the non-partisan Pew Research Center. A majority of voters for both parties have ""very unfavorable"" views of the other party - a first since Pew began asking the question in 1992 - and trust in government is hovering near all-time lows.""These indicators reflect inter-group tensions that can translate into everything from coarse discourse or low levels of aggression all the way up to extremist acts
column24: director of the Center for the Study of Hate and Extremism at California State University.     While much of the venom has been aimed at immigrants
column25: African Americans and other groups typically aligned with Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton
column26: Republicans also have faced vitriol and hostility.Much of the debate over extremism has focused on the so-called Alt-Right
column27: a loose-knit movement of white nationalists
column28: anti-Semites and immigration foes that has emerged from the political shadows to align itself with the Trump campaign.

column1: Trump's vows to build a wall on the Mexican border
column2: deport millions of illegal immigrants and scrutinize Muslims for ties to terrorism have energized the Alt-Right community. Such rhetoric has helped legitimize the Alt-Right's concerns about an erosion of the country's white
column3: Christian majority
column4: said Michael Hill
column5: a self-described white supremacist
column6: anti-Semite and xenophobe who heads the League of the South
column7: a ""Southern Nationalist"" group dedicated to creating an independent ""white man's land.""    ""The general political climate that sort of surrounds his campaign has been very fruitful
column10: Hill said.    Similar nationalist undercurrents have stirred other countries
column11: from Russia to Japan to Britain. Last summer
column12: as Britain's debate over leaving the European Union reached a fever pitch
column15: was shot and stabbed in the street. Murder suspect Thomas Mair proclaimed ""death to traitors
column16: freedom for Britain.""    In the United States
column18: vandalism and violence are cropping up regularly. In Mississippi
column19: a black church was burned and painted with ""Vote Trump."" In North Carolina
column20: a county Republican office was set ablaze last month and a nearby building spray painted with ""Nazi Republicans leave town."" In Ohio
column21: a truck load of manure was dumped at a Democratic campaign office. In Utah
column22: a man displaying Trump yard signs found KKK graffiti on his car. In Wisconsin
column23: a fan at a college football game wore a President Barack Obama mask with a noose on his neck. Neither the Trump nor the Clinton campaigns responded to requests for comment.

column1: EXTREMISM GOES MAINSTREAM
Trump's positions are consistent with the Alt-Right goal of ""slowing the dispossession of whites
column2: said Jared Taylor
column3: a white nationalist whose website
column4: American Renaissance
column5: is a movement favorite. But the media is over-hyping his support within the Alt-Right ""in an attempt to discredit him
column6: Taylor added.    Trump has been criticized by both Democrats and some Republicans for being slow to condemn the more extreme elements of the political right. But when a leading KKK newspaper ran a pro-Trump story on its front page last week
column7: his campaign immediately issued a statement rejecting the ""repulsive"" article.    Taylor
column8: Hill and other Alt-Right figures say they don't advocate or condone vandalism or violence. They dismiss the notion that their rhetoric constitutes hate speech
column9: arguing that their vilification by the left is far more hateful.    Left-wing extremists do have a history of aggressive confrontation with people or groups seen as fascist or racist
column11: of the Southern Poverty Law Center
column12: an organization that monitors extremist movements. ""There's usually more violence from the anti-racists than the racists

column1: The free speech provisions of the U.S. Constitution's First Amendment grant broad protections for inflammatory rhetoric. But state and federal statutes do give law enforcement agencies authority to investigate and prosecute ""hate crimes"" motivated by bias against a race
column2: ethnicity
column3: religion
column4: disability or sexual orientation.    A 6 percent increase in hate crimes documented last year by the California State University researchers showed relatively little underlying change in attacks against most minority groups. But crimes against Muslims rose 86 percent.Some who study and work in the political arena believe there has been a general erosion in civility that began long before the start of the current presidential race.Craig Dunn
column5: Republican party chairman for Howard County
column8: says that a minority of extreme voices are being amplified over the Internet and social media
column9: fueling ""a general breakdown in civility.""    Local officials worry about how their community is being affected.""The atmosphere is ""more volatile
column12: a Democrat. The graffiti attacks were deeply troubling
column13: he adds. ""I don't remember anything like this ever happening here.""Monica Fowler
column15: who had ""KKK"" sprayed on her Democratic yard signs
column16: is struggling with the attacks. ""It's okay to disagree
column17: she says. ""But if what you're doing is going to scare or harm another person
column18: how dare you.""(This story corrects in the ninth paragraph to state that trust
column20: in government is near all-time lows Note: paragraph 2 contains language that may offend some readers) (Additional reporting by Tim Reid in Los Angeles and Guy Faulconbridge in London. Editing by Stuart Grudgings.)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-mexico-border-idUSKBN13309K	Mexicans on U.S. border fear economic catastrophe if Trump wins	"
By Joanna Zuckerman Bernstein  and David Alire Garcia
| TIJUANA/NOGALES

""But this has been analyzed by both the United States and by Mexico and it's suicide for both countries.""Mexican business leaders say about 40 percent of the average Mexican factory export is made of U.S. content and argue the two manufacturing sectors are so closely intertwined that it is impossible to take steps against one without damaging the other.Trump

Rarely have Mexicans expressed such strong views about U.S. presidential candidates as during the current campaign.Mexicans favor Clinton in the race by 10 to 1

column10: because of what comes out of his mouth. He doesn't like us Mexicans

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-elections-congress-idUSKBN13218S	Democrats see FBI controversy hurting chances in U.S. Congress races	"
By Richard Cowan
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Senior Democrats said on Monday their chances of winning control of the U.S. House of Representatives had been hurt by the FBI's surprise announcement last month that Hillary Clinton's email practices were again figuring in a federal investigation.Voters will go to the polls on Tuesday to choose Democrat Clinton or Republican Donald Trump for president
column2: but also to fill 34 U.S. Senate seats in the 100-chamber body and all 435 House seats.Both the House and Senate are currently controlled by Republicans.FBI Director James Comey's letter to Congress in late October that the agency would examine newly found emails that might pertain to Clinton's use of a private server while she was secretary of state
column3: ""had a tremendous adverse impact with our standing with independents
column4: said Representative James Clyburn
column5: a member of the House Democratic leadership
column6: referring to independent voters.House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi
column7: while calling Comey's action ""out of line
column8: said it resulted in a spike in small campaign donations.But she added: ""We would be in a better place (without the letter) and in the manner he did it.""Clyburn's and Pelosi's remarks
column10: were delivered during a phone call House Democratic leaders had with rank-and-file members. Continued Republican control of Congress could stymie the legislative agenda put forth by Clinton if she wins the presidency. A Trump win along with a Republican Congress could spell doom for Democratic President Barack Obama's landmark healthcare law known as Obamacare
column11: which has been the target of a sustained attack by Republican lawmakers.If voters hand power to Democrats in either chamber
column12: 2017 will likely bring a more moderate bent to bills that lawmakers send to the new president for signing into law.A senior Democratic aide said the October controversy
column13: which consumed U.S. political campaigns for over a week
column14: could reduce by at least 10 the number of House seats Democrats may be able to capture from Republicans on Election Day.

column1: Comey informed Congress on Sunday that he was standing by his July decision that no criminal charges were warranted against the Democratic presidential candidate in the emails investigation.But coming only two days before national elections
column2: Comey's latest decision may have come too late for Democrats who were hoping for big wins on Tuesday to help them regain control of the House for the first time since 2010 and the Senate for the first time since 2014.""It's terribly damaging to us
column3: the aide said
column4: adding that Clinton's support in battleground states could be depressed
column5: which in turn would hurt the party's House candidates.With that in mind
column6: the aide said Democrats could end up gaining only 12 to 16 House seats on Tuesday
column7: instead of the 30 or so needed to win back the chamber.Representative Tom Cole
column9: said in a telephone interview he found it ""mystifying in how he (Comey) has interjected himself in the election on three different occasions in ways that were probably inappropriate.""Cole was referring to the initial announcement in July that Clinton would not be prosecuted
column10: the late October letter to Congress that FBI agents were again reviewing the issue and Sunday's information that the agency would not change its July findings.

column1: Of Sunday's good news for Clinton
column2: the Oklahoma lawmaker said: ""I think it certainly takes a little steam out of the Republicans.""To win control of the Senate outright
column3: Democrats would have to score a net gain of five seats. Republicans currently hold 54 Senate seats to 44 Democratic seats and two independents who align themselves with Democrats.For much of the autumn campaign
column4: political analysts were projecting Democrats would pick up anywhere from four to seven Senate seats.TIGHT SENATE CONTESTS

column1: The outcome of the presidential race is expected to have a major impact on the outcome of the congressional campaigns. In recent decades
column2: the party that wins the White House has usually fared better in congressional races too.For most of the 2016 campaign season
column3: the Senate races have been center stage
column4: as Democrats fielded some strong challengers to Republican incumbents.Among them are Missouri Secretary of State Jason Kander
column5: who is giving Republican Senator Roy Blunt an unexpectedly stiff challenge
column6: and former environmental official Katie McGinty
column7: who could unseat Republican Senator Pat Toomey in Pennsylvania.  John McCain
column8: the Vietnam War hero and 2008 Republican presidential nominee who has served in the Senate for 30 years
column9: appears headed to re-election in a race that has been unusually competitive for him.A possible 50-50 tie following Tuesday's elections would mean that the next vice president would cast the tie-breaking vote and determine which party controls the Senate.The Senate that will be sworn in on Jan. 3
column10: whether it is held by Republicans or Democrats
column11: will face a weighty decision early on: voting on a U.S. Supreme Court justice to replace the conservative Justice Antonin Scalia
column12: who died last February.Since that time
column13: Senate Republicans have refused to consider Obama's nomination of federal judge Merrick Garland
column14: arguing the next president should pick a nominee for Senate review.Other issues confronting Congress next year include illegal immigration and border security
column15: the need to raise U.S. borrowing authority
column16: something some conservative Republicans oppose without substantial budget cuts
column17: and possible approval of free-trade deals with Pacific Rim countries and Europe if negotiations on the latter conclude successfully. (Reporting by Richard Cowan and Susan Cornwell; Editing by Jonathan Oatis and Peter Cooney)"
